Homage to the pratyekabuddhas who rejoice, homage to the twelve pratyekabuddhas who fell like rain, homage to the ten pratyekabuddhas with the same name of VÄrÄá¹‡a, homage to the pratyekabuddhas whose bodies were like fire, homage to the pratyekabuddhas who attained enlightenment together, homage to the pratyekabuddha MahÄnÄman, homage to the pratyekabuddha ManodhÄrin, homage to the pratyekabuddha KeÅ›ava, homage to the pratyekabuddha Subhadra, homage to the pratyekabuddha Vá¹›ddha. I take refuge in immeasurable and boundless pratyekabuddhas such as these.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
Now, having repented all karmas in general, I will next repent each one in detail.
Whether general or specific, coarse or subtle, light or heavy, spoken or unspoken, I wish for all to be extinguished according to their type.
As for specific repentance, I will first repent the three offenses of the body, then the four offenses of the mouth, and the remaining hindrances I will repent in order with bowed head.

As for the three karmas of the body, the first is killing, as explained in the sutras. One can use oneself as a model, not killing and not wielding a staff. Although there is a difference between humans and animals, they all cherish their lives and fear death.

If one investigates these sentient beings, from beginningless time they may have been one's parents, siblings, or relatives. Due to karmic causes and conditions, they transmigrate through the six realms, coming to life and dying, changing forms and transforming, and no longer recognize each other. Yet now one harms them and eats their flesh, cutting off the seeds of great compassion.
Therefore, the Buddha said:
Even if one obtains leftover food, one should think of it as eating one's child's flesh in a famine. How much more so for eating fish and meat?
He also said:
Those who kill sentient beings for profit and buy the flesh of sentient beings with money,
both commit evil karma and fall into the wailing hell after death.
Therefore, one should know that killing and eating have sins as deep as the ocean and offenses as heavy as Mount Sumeru.
However, disciples, from beginningless time until now, not encountering good friends, have all created this karma.
Therefore, the sutra says that the sin of killing can cause sentient beings to fall into the hells and hungry ghost realms to suffer.

If in the animal realm, one will receive the bodies of tigers, dogs, foxes, wolves, hawks, and falcons, or the bodies of poisonous snakes, vipers, and scorpions, always harboring evil thoughts, or the bodies of deer, bears, and brown bears, always harboring fear.
If reborn among humans, one will obtain two kinds of karmic retribution:
First, many illnesses;
Second, cutting off life.
Killing and devouring have such immeasurable and various kinds of evil karmic retributions.
Therefore, disciples!
Today, I bow my head and take refuge in the Buddha with utmost sincerity.

Homage to the Buddha who Eliminates All Fears in the East, Homage to the Buddha of the Sun and Moon Lamp in the South, Homage to the Buddha of Awakened Flower Light in the West, Homage to the Buddha who Gives Rise to Merits in the North, Homage to the Buddha who Removes the Darkness of All Delusions in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha of No Birth and Freedom in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha of Great Divine Powers in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha of Mind Free from Defilements in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha of the Same Appearance as Space in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha of Lapis Lazuli Treasury in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space, like this.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, this mind and consciousness have always harbored vicious thoughts without any compassion. Either out of greed, anger, ignorance, or arrogance, one may kill, vow to kill, or kill through spells, or break through lakes and ponds, burn mountains and fields, hunt and fish, or set fires with the wind, flying hawks and releasing dogs, harming all sentient beings of the six realms. Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge and repent.

Or using traps, snares, spears, halberds, bows, crossbows, slings, to shoot flying birds and running beasts, or using nets, traps, and fishing hooks, to scoop up aquatic creatures such as fish, turtles, alligators, shrimp, clams, oysters, and other creatures that live in water, causing those that live in water, on land, and in the air to have no place to hide, or raising chickens, pigs, cows, sheep, dogs, pigs, geese, ducks, and other such creatures, for one's own kitchen, or selling them to others for slaughter, causing them to die with mournful cries, their feathers and fur falling off, their scales and shells damaged, their bodies and heads separated, their bones and flesh scattered, skinned, butchered, roasted, boiled, and grilled, inflicting cruel and painful punishments unjustly.

But taking only a momentary pleasure in the mouth, the taste is very little, no more than the tip of the tongue, three inches long, yet the retribution for that sin brings misfortune for endless kalpas.
Such sins I now confess with utmost sincerity, taking refuge and repenting.

Furthermore, from beginningless time until today, we have either raised armies to attack each other, fought battles, faced each other, and killed each other, or killed others ourselves or ordered others to kill, or rejoiced upon hearing of killing, or engaged in butchering, debt collection, and execution, slaughtering the lives of others and acting without compassion, or indulged in anger, brandishing weapons and holding knives, either beheading or stabbing, or pushing into pits or ravines, or drowning in water, or blocking holes and destroying nests with earth and stones, or using carts and horses to trample and crush all beings.
Like this, our offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today we confess and take refuge.
Furthermore, from beginningless time until now, we have either irrigated dry fields, aborted fetuses, destroyed eggs,
damaged nests, used poisonous drugs and sorcery to harm and kill beings, tilled the soil, dug the ground, planted fields and gardens,
raised silkworms, boiled cocoons, raised cats and mice, causing great harm and killing, or beaten mosquitoes, flies, and maggots,

Flies, bees, scorpions, mosquitoes, fleas, lice, or burning garbage, opening and closing ditches and canals, unjustly harming all, or eating fruits, using grains, water, or vegetables, killing indiscriminately, or

Flies, bees, scorpions, lice, fleas, or burning to remove rubbish, digging ditches and canals, unjustly harming all, or eating fruits, using grains, water, or vegetables to kill living beings, or burning firewood or exposing lamps and candles to burn insects, or eating sauces and vinegar without

looking at the stirring, or pouring boiling water to kill ants, in this way, up to walking, standing, sitting, and lying down in the four deportments, always injuring and killing the subtle living beings in the air and on the ground.
Disciples!
Because of the ignorance of ordinary beings, one is not aware and does not know, today revealing and taking refuge in repentance.
Moreover, disciples!

From beginningless time up to the present, using whips, sticks, shackles, fetters, pressing, standing, beating, striking, kicking with hands and feet, binding, caging, and cutting off water and grain, in this way, all kinds of evil means tormenting living beings.
Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge in the Buddhas of the ten directions, the honored Dharma, and the holy assembly, and repent with utmost sincerity.

May the disciples, by means of the merit generated from repenting of the offenses of killing and so forth, wish to be born in every life with an adamantine body and an infinite lifespan, forever free from resentment and enmity, without thoughts of killing and harming, and attain the state of regarding all beings as one's only child. If one sees those in danger and distress, one should not spare one's body or life but skillfully rescue and liberate them. Only then should one expound the subtle and correct Dharma for them, enabling all beings who see one's form or shadow to enjoy peace and happiness, and upon hearing one's name or voice, all fears and anxieties will be eliminated.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Mahayana Lotus Treasure-Reaching Monk, in which he enters the Flowing Fire Hell.
Why is it called the Flowing Fire Hell?

The hell is two hundred yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls and covered with an iron net above, with fierce flames blazing and billowing smoke everywhere. Iron spikes are scattered all over the ground, and the fires in the hell flow and billow with smoke and flames.
In the west gate, there are six hundred sinners crying out in loud voices, their entire bodies burning with raging flames. These sinful monks cried out, saying:
What sins have we committed to come into this place?
They writhed and rolled around, refusing to move forward.

The horse-headed rakshasa slapped his ears with his hands, and fire came out of his mouth and eyes. He held a sharp blade and aimed it at their heads to chop them. There were also hungry dogs that came to eat their flesh, hungry ghosts that came to drink their blood, and flying birds that came to gnaw on their marrow.

The horse-headed rakshasa grabbed their arms and pulled them. The fire burning in his hands immediately scorched them, and the flowing fire drenched their bodies, burning them all over. In a single day and night, they suffered countless punishments, dying a thousand times and being reborn a thousand times, dying ten thousand times and being reborn ten thousand times.
Baodala asked the horse-headed rakshasa:
For what reasons did these monks undergo such punishments?
The horse-headed rakshasa replied to Baodala:

These monks received the Buddha's pure precepts but did not uphold them purely. They accepted people's offerings of toothpicks, mouthwash, fragrant baths, and went out into the world holding their alms bowls, but their behavior while begging for food resembled that of a monk in form only, without any sense of shame. For these reasons, they fell into this hell.
When Baodala heard this, he wept with tears streaming down his face, and then spoke a verse:
How is it that those without bonds are thrown back into prison?
How is it that those who have escaped birth and death are thrown back into the three evil paths?ğŸ”½How is it that one encounters a floating log, sees the light, and then returns to darkness?
How is it that blowing out a fire suddenly causes it to blaze up again?
Those who practice purity and liberation now undergo great suffering.
Bodhisattva Baodala spoke the verse and left.
